Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• Indicate how continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• Be signed and dated.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and
your contract. Review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with
any questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact area manager Jessica VandenHeuvel at (616) 204-6992.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI R 400.4159 Youth restraint; pregnant youth; reduction,
Section prevention; prohibited.
Description (5) In the event a restraint occurs, it must be performed in a
manner that is safe, appropriate, and proportionate to the severity
of the youth’s behavior, chronological and developmental age,
size, gender, physical condition, medical condition, psychiatric
condition, and personal history, including any history of trauma,
and must be done in a manner consistent with the youth’s
treatment plan.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff put the youth in restraints for over 5 minutes because they
were attempting suicide. Youth has marks as a result of the
restraints.
Investigation On 02/01/2023 a telephone call was made to the DHHS specialist.
She was advised that Vassar Police Department had been called
to the facility the night of the incident and Youth A did not disclose
any of the reported concerns to law enforcement. Youth A was
transferred to the hospital via ambulance. The DHHS specialist
advised that law enforcement would not be moving forward with a
criminal investigation unless further information is obtained
regarding a crime being committed.
On 02/07/2023 an in-person meeting was held with the
complainant. No additional concerns were provided.
On 02/07/2023 an in-person interview was held with Youth A. The
DHHS specialist also participated in the interview. She has been
at the facility for three months and is currently placed in Unit 1.
Youth A advised that she had received bruises when she was
“restrained” by staff. She recalled that the bruise had happened
on the night that she expressed concern at the facility. Youth A
reported that she was restrained by Youth B and Youth D. Youth
A stated that the youth were restraining her because they were
trying to keep her safe. Youth A reported that her behavior
included trying to run, trying to cut herself and trying to kill herself.
She recalled that Youth B and Youth D threw her to the ground.
2

She reported that Youth C was present but did not try to assist in
the restraint. Youth A reported that the youth did not use proper
restraint techniques when restraining her. She reported that youth
were trying to suffocate her and placed a pillow over her face.
Youth A reported this is the first time she has been restrained and
it occurred between 6pm and 9pm. Youth A reported two staff
present, but staff try not to restrain youth. She reported that she
told staff and supervision, but the youth denied that the incident
occurred. Youth A reported that the supervisor failed to ask Staff
7 about what occurred. Youth A reported that Youth E was there
with her one-on-one staff, who was Staff 7. She denied that the
staff saw anything. Youth A reported that she was later restrained
by Staff 7 and Staff 8. She reported it as a standing restraint, and
they kept their hands behind her back. She recalled the restraint
lasted for about 10 minutes. Staff 1 came in and demonstrated to
staff how to properly engage the youth in a restraint and then left.
Youth A stated she had bruising but does not know where it came
from.
On 02/07/2023 an in-person meeting occurred at Vassar House
with Youth B. The DHHS specialist was also present. Youth B
has been at the facility since April of 2022 and is in Unit 1. Youth
B reported that Youth A is in her unit and often acts up. She runs
away and will also walk around naked and spit on people. She
recalled that there was an incident about a week ago when Youth
A was trying to harm herself. Youth B reported that staff was just
watching, so her and Youth D intervened. She reported that the
staff told them not to touch Youth A, but didn’t take any other
actions to redirect. Youth B reported that Youth A was banging
her head on everything, putting her mouth on the electrical socket
and trying to rip her shirt to tie around her neck. Youth B stated
that Youth A usually listens to her and Youth D. Youth B denied
putting any bruising on Youth A. She denied that the staff put any
bruises on Youth A, she stated the bruising was from Youth A
biting herself. She further denied that the staff told them to
restrain Youth A. Youth B denied that they placed Youth A in a
restraint on the floor. She reported that the youth fell to the floor
on her own. Youth B reported that Staff 1 came in to pass
medications and after confirming that the youth were properly
clothed, he showed Staff 7 and Staff 8 how to put Youth A in a
standing restraint. Youth B added that staff have been saying that
they “can’t” touch the youth. Youth B reported that the staff are
scared.
On 02/07/2023 an in-person meeting occurred at Vassar House
with Youth C. The DHHS specialist was also present. She
3

reported she moved units today and was previously in Unit 1.
Youth C confirmed she was in a unit with Youth A. She reported
that the youth is "very bipolar" and acts out a lot. Youth C
reported that Youth A began to act out after dinner. Youth C
reported that Youth B and Youth D attempted to redirect the
behavior of Youth A. She further reported that when youth make
an attempt to restrain or redirect Youth A, the staff just sit there
and watch. She reported that Staff 3 and Staff 7 were watching
today. Youth C denied Youth A was ever restrained by staff after
she was restrained by the other youth. Youth C feels as if youth
restrain more than the staff do.
On 02/07/2023 an in-person meeting occurred at Vassar House
with Youth D. The DHHS specialist was also present. She was in
Unit 1 but is now in Unit 4. Youth D reported that Youth A often
acts out and makes messes in the unit. Youth A will attempt
to run away from the facility. Youth D denied she's ever restrained
Youth A and denied seeing other youth do so. Youth D reported
that Youth A was recently ripping her shirt in order to wrap a piece
of it around her neck. She said she grabbed a piece of the shirt
from the Youth’s neck, but reported that is all that she did. She
denied touching Youth A and said no one else restrained her.
She reported that Youth A was eventually placed in a standing
restraint because she was unsafe. She described this action as
staff grabbing your wrist and holding your upper arm and standing
there. She recalled that Youth A was attempting to get away from
the staff and also was trying to hit them, but couldn't. Youth D said
she wasn't sure who all was in her unit when this occurred.
On 02/07/2023 an in-person meeting occurred at Vassar House
with Staff 1. The DHHS specialist was also present. He typically
works second shift. He denied having any discipline within his
employee file. The allegations were addressed with Staff 1. He
confirmed being the supervisor on duty the night of the incident.
He recalled Youth A was running around the unit, picking at the
electrical socket, trying to wrap her shirt around her neck and
engaging in other inappropriate behavior. He said when he
initially entered the unit, he stood back because of being told that
Youth A had ripped her shirt and he wasn't sure if she was naked
or not. Once he confirmed that she wasn't, he went over to her p-
aisle area and advised Staff 3 and Staff 7 to place Youth A in a
standing hold. He said the staff were struggling at first and he had
to show them how to perform the proper hold. He further recalled
that Youth A claimed to have bruising after the incident. He
looked at the youth and reported that he found her arm to be red,
but denied any bruising after the incident. He said Youth A was
4

hitting her arm and biting it which he believed caused the injury.
He said she later went to the hospital due to saying she wanted to
harm herself. Staff 1 confirmed other youth assisted staff with
Youth A by talking to her. Staff 1 recalled when he entered the
unit and was able to see Youth A, she was on the floor with two
other youth restraining her. He stated he immediately told the
youth to get up and advised that they weren't allowed to do this.
He said this was done in Youth A's p-aisle and she was laying on
her stomach. He said the staff were standing there and he called
another supervisor for assistance. Staff 1 also reported that other
youth were attempting to assist with Youth A and had to be
redirected to not do this. Staff 1 denied that the youth were in a
"full restraint" with Youth A, but said Youth B and Youth D were
both on the ground with Youth A. Staff 1 denied seeing this
before or having knowledge of staff allowing youth to restrain
other youth. He believed the youth were genuinely trying to help
Youth A.
On 02/22/2023 an in-person interview was held with Staff 2 at
Vassar House. The DHHS specialist was also present. She has
worked at the facility since November of 2022 but noted she
previously worked for the agency for seven years. She is a youth
care worker and typically works first shift. Staff 2 reported that she
is familiar with Youth A and reported she is doing well now. She
said previously, Youth A was acting out a lot. This would consist of
the youth harming herself, ripping her shirts to tie around her
neck, taking boards off the walls in the unit, standing on her
dresser and running out of her unit. Staff 2 said they would allow
Youth A to do these behaviors because she wasn't harming
herself or others. Staff 2 confirmed she's been involved in a
restraint with Youth A. She recalled she has been a part of both a
standing and team restraint with Youth A. Staff 2 denied seeing
other youth restrain Youth A or them attempting to intervene
during a restraint. She reported that she has never had to tell
other youth to stop intervening when Youth A was acting out.
Staff 2 denied there being a time where youth were helping get
Youth A out of the bathroom or drag her across the floor. She
said youth may try to talk Youth A down, but that's it. Staff 2 said
if she were to see youth attempt to restrain another youth, she
would tell them to stop because they aren't supposed to touch one
another like that.
On 02/22/2023 an in-person meeting was held with Staff 3 at
Vassar House. The DHHS specialist was also present. Staff 3
has worked at the facility since September as a youth care worker.
She typically works first shift. She reported that she does not work
5

with Youth A often. She is familiar with Youth A being off of her
safety plan, stating she is doing better than she was previously.
She recalled the inappropriate behavior of Youth A and denied
ever having to restrain her. Staff 3 denied staff are afraid to
intervene with the youth or restrain them. She denied ever seeing
Youth A run into the bathroom to act out. She also denied other
youth having ever restrained Youth A. She has witnessed youth
provide "peer support" which she described as helping the youth
to remain on task or motivate other youth. Staff 3 identified Youth
B and Youth D as the main youth who provide "peer support" to
Youth A. She denied seeing them intervene with Youth A
physically.
On 02/22/2023 an in-person meeting was held with Staff 4 at
Vassar House. The DHHS specialist was also present. She has
worked at the facility since 2019 and is a youth care worker. She
reported that she typically works first shift. She reported that the
behaviors of Youth A have improved, but that she previously
engaged in very inappropriate behavior within the unit. She said
Youth A would talk in a baby voice, wouldn't follow redirection,
would self-harm by ripping up her clothing and tying it around her
neck and going AWOL. Staff 4 confirmed she was working the
day of the incident. She said she couldn't remember exactly what
was going on but reported that Youth A was upset and having an
episode. She wasn't in the unit but was called down there to assist
by Staff 1. By the time Staff 4 arrived, she reported that the youth
was in a standing restraint with Staff 7 and Staff 8. She further
reported that Staff 1 was advising on proper technique for the
restraint. She denied that Youth A was placed in a team restraint.
She denied seeing any youth restraining Youth A and denied this
has occurred before. She reported the youth may tell one another
to calm down, but they don't get involved in restraints. She
reported that the standing restraint was done appropriately. She
reported that Youth A was fighting and attempting to get out of the
restraint and as a result her arm was red, but noted this was
normal due to her light skin and attempting to get away.
On 02/22/2023 an in-person meeting was held with Staff 5 at
Vassar House. The DHHS specialist was also present. She has
worked at the facility for two years. She was a youth care worker,
but is now a case manager. She transitioned to this new position
last month. She denied she was the staff in Youth A’s unit that
day. She said she volunteered to ride with her to the hospital. She
recalled Youth A initially refused to go with them but later agreed.
Staff 4 denied ever seeing other youth restrain Youth A or any
other youth. She doesn't believe the staff are afraid to intervene
6

or restrain the youth. She said there are times some youth may
act like "mini staff", but she redirects this behavior. She confirmed
that youth provide "peer support" which she describes as talking to
youth and finding out what's wrong if something is bothering them.
Staff 3 denied seeing Staff 7 or Staff 8 be hesitant to intervene
when there is a crisis.
On 02/28/2023 an in-person meeting was held with Staff 6 at
Vassar House. The DHHS specialist was also present. She has
worked at the facility for six months as a youth care worker. She
typically works second shift. Staff 6 reported that when Youth A is
escalated, almost all the youth in the unit will talk to her to help
her calm down. She denied there were any particular youth who
reached out to Youth A. Staff 6 reported that when necessary,
staff will manage the environment and redirect youth regarding
behavior, tones and space. She reported they will have to do this
until the situation is under control. Staff 6 denied seeing any of
the youth restraint Youth A or any other youth. She said some of
the youth will ask them if they want them to assist and they are
told no. Staff 6 reported it is common for Youth A to run into the
bathroom out of line of sight. She said the staff will always follow.
She denied any youth follow Youth A when she goes into the
bathroom. She said the staff will talk to her and attempt to get her
to calm down. She denied staff or youth have dragged Youth A
out of the bathroom.
On 02/28/2023 an in-person meeting was held with Staff 7 at
Vassar House. The DHHS specialist was also present. Staff 7
has worked at the facility since 1/4/2023 as a youth care worker.
She works second shift and is not in a particular unit. The
allegations were addressed with Staff 7. She recalled that Youth
A was having a bad day and was escalated when they got on
shift. Staff 7 recalled that there were two youth, Youth B and
Youth D who were overly involved in what was going on with
Youth A. She recalled that they didn't have boundaries and were
too close to Youth A. She reported that the youth would be
“posting” at the door when Youth A attempted to run. She
described that as standing in front of the doors that lead outside
so the youth can't leave. She believed the youth were trying to
help them but said this wasn't allowed. Staff 7 denies seeing youth
in the unit hold down Youth A. She reported that she also talked
to Staff 8 about the youth doing things they weren't supposed to
do and the need to redirect them. She reported that she and Staff
8 would redirect them; however, noted Staff 8 is more "soft
spoken" and was sitting on the other side of the unit. Staff 7 said
they eventually called the supervisor (Staff 1) as Youth A became
7

more escalated and began to pull stuff off the walls and was biting
herself. She recalled that Staff 1 advised them to place Youth A in
a standing restraint. She reported that when Staff 1 came into the
unit, Youth A was in her p-aisle with the Youth B and Youth D.
Staff 7 denied they were ever on the ground or that Youth B and
Youth D restrained Youth A. When asked why her information
would conflict with what was reported by Staff 1 and other youth
throughout the investigation, she stated that she must have saw
the situation differently than the supervisor or the youth. She
initially denied that Youth A fought the restraint, but then indicated
that she did fight it “a little bit”. Staff 7 reported that she hates
having to place youth in a restraint but denied she would ever not
do one when needed. She believed restraints are a liability and
could go wrong. Staff 7 reported that she feels there is definitely a
boundary issue at the facility. She said this was the first time she
saw youth act like "mini staff".
On 02/28/2023 an in-person meeting was held with Staff 8 at
Vassar House. The DHHS specialist was also present. She has
worked at the facility for four years as a youth care worker.
Staff 8 reported that the youth basically do whatever they want to
do. The staff will redirect them or contact supervisor when there
are issues. She said they will restrain youth when they are told to
restrain; however, they have to call a supervisor first and they
have to give them the "green light" to restrain youth. Staff 8
recalled her and Staff 7 attempting to redirect Youth A. She
confirmed that Youth B and Youth D were attempting to help keep
Youth A in the unit and keep her safe. She recalled that Youth B
and Youth D grabbed Youth A and she told them not to do this
and to leave her alone. She reported that Youth B and Youth D
were on the floor with Youth A and attempting to restrain her.
Youth A was face down near her bed and was attempting to hit
her head on the floor. She reported that both Youth B and Youth D
held Youth A to the ground. Staff 8 reported telling the youth to
stop. This is when she called an SST (supervisor) to assist and
she reported this is when the youth stopped restraining Youth A.
Staff 8 reported that when Staff 1 arrived the behaviors of Youth A
got worse, and they were advised to place her in a standing hold
restraint. Staff 8 stated that they did not restrain Youth A sooner
as management is telling them they are “hands free”. She
recalled that day was the first time she ever saw youth restraining
other youth. She also said the youth were "half ass listening" to
them when they were attempting to redirect them. She described
the day as being "chaotic" and the youth were "fueling the fire" to
the way Youth A was acting.
8

Incident reports involving Youth A: There were three incident
reports from the day of the incident. They noted Youth A’s
attempt to go AWOL and behavior that involved ripping off her
shirt and trying to wrap it around her neck, playing with electrical
sockets, and attempting to self-harm and biting herself. It also
documented her biting her left arm and scratching herself leaving
a bruise to her arm. Youth A was restrained at 8:25 p.m. She
was placed in a standing restraint because she was running
around the unit, attempting to go outside and presenting as a risk
to herself. The police were called, and Youth A was transported
to the hospital via ambulance. No injuries were documented on
the incident report from the day of this incident. The staff involved
were Staff 4, Staff 7 and Staff 8.
Analysis After completion of the interviews, staff placed Youth A in a
standing restraint that was performed in a manner that is safe,
appropriate, and proportionate to the severity of the youth’s
behavior.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(a) Routine and emergency medical, and dental, and behavioral
health care.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth is sick and staff refused to take youth to the hospital.
Investigation On 02/07/2023 an in-person interview was held with Youth A. The
DHHS specialist also participated in the interview. Youth A
indicated she had bruising to her upper arm but she wasn't sure
where it came from. She confirmed going to the hospital but
denied telling or showing the hospital staff any bruising. She also
denied telling hospital staff that she didn't feel well. Youth A did
not indicate whether she had asked to go to the hospital.
On 02/22/2023 an in-person meeting was held with Staff 5 at
Vassar House. The DHHS specialist was also present. She has
worked at the facility for two years. She was previously a youth
care worker but is now employed as a case manager. Staff 5
reported that she was not in the Unit that day but volunteered to
ride with Youth A to the hospital. She reported Youth A was going
to the hospital due to her attempting to engage in self harm and
9

her suicidal ideations. She recalled Youth A initially refused to go
with them but later agreed.
On 02/07/2023 an in-person meeting occurred at Vassar House
with Staff 1. The DHHS specialist was also present. Staff 1
reported that he typically works second shift. He denied having
any discipline within his employee file. The allegations were
addressed with Staff 1. He confirmed being the supervisor on duty
the night of the incident. He recalled Youth A was running around
the unit, picking at the electrical socket, trying to wrap her shirt
around her neck and engaging in other inappropriate behavior.
He said Youth A was hitting her arm and biting it which he
believed caused the injury that she had. Staff 1 reported that
Youth A was later transported to the hospital via ambulance due
to saying she wanted to harm herself.
The medical documentation from Saginaw Covenant Hospital was
reviewed. It documented that Youth A was seen in the emergency
room on 1/31/2023. She was taken to the hospital via ambulance
for suicidal ideations. There were no marks or bruises
documented in the medical report. She was discharged back to
Wolverine Human Services.
Analysis At the conclusion of the investigation, there was no evidence to
support that staff refused to take a youth to obtain medical care.
Interviews and medical documentation confirm that Youth A was
taken to the hospital and received medical care.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff
Section (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency’s program statement and to provide for
the continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Staff failed to intervene when youth were fighting and engaging in
self-harming behavior.

got worse, and they were advised to place her in a standing hold
restraint. Staff 8 stated that they did not restrain Youth A sooner
as management is telling them they are “hands free”.
Staff 7 and Staff 8 noted in their interviews that they were out of
ratio during the incident. However, review of staff schedule, youth
census and supervision requirements, there were 5 youth on the
unit. One youth required a one-to-one. There were two staff, Staff
7 and Staff 8 working on the unit. The facilities ratio is 1 staff to 4
youth. The agency was within ratio during this incident.
Analysis At the conclusion of the investigation, there was sufficient
evidence to confirm that the staff involved failed to provide for the
protection of the youth. Youth that were interviewed denied that
they were advised to engage in restraints but indicated that they
did engage as they felt the need to keep Youth A safe as staff
were not responding and providing protection for the youth.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
